												I bought this game on sale for very cheap, and while I can't say it's not worth what I paid, because it most certainly is, I just think there was a lot of wasted potential here. The thing is, puzzles in general can be very fun and rewarding, or very frustrating. I think the main thing that makes a puzzle frustrating is when you simply don't have enough information to solve it. Sure, it's a valuable life skill to be able to solve problems even when you don't have all the tools, but those kinds of problems are supposed to give you real life rewards, not present themselves as games and take your money.My biggest complaint about this game is that it relies heavily on things it never gives you a chance to understand, particularly timing. Many of the puzzles are very simple in a spatial sense, but require timing movements exactly so that you can interweave block paths. However, the game doesn't let you change the speed of the runs, and it's not consistent between different runs. Furthermore, some of the harder puzzles have blocks traveling at different speeds. As if that wasn't enough, it seems the game doesn't even judge collisions based on a notion of which block occupies which tile, but rather it actually uses hit detection, so blocks entering and leaving a tile at about the same time can still collide by touching corners for a split second. This makes some of the puzzles unnecessarily trial-and-error in nature, with the player just switching blocks around between multiple nearly identical solutions in spatial terms which result in slightly different timing, in the hopes that one of them will eventually produce the correct result. A good puzzle game shouldn't be designed to make you just randomly try things until one works.Another complain I have is that there's no ability to zoom the camera in or out as far as I can tell. You can rotate the camera, but the level of zoom is consistently too close or far to clearly see all of the map. The game would've also benefitted from a square lense (orthogonal view if I remember correctly from 3D modeling) rather than an eye-type lense, because several of the puzzles have you dropping blocks from one platform down to another below it, and trying to line up the camera from above to see what will happen isn't very effective.All in all, it's an interesting concept for a game that had potential, but it feels like it was developed to work against you and force you into trial-and-error runs rather than actually thinking about space and time in discrete units with well-defined, known rates of movement. This game could've been more fun in 2D 20 years ago. I found myself using the hints (which make it way too easy) and trial-and-error to solve the harder puzzles, because it didn't even feel like cheating when that's about what I would do without the hints anyway.

												From the same developers as Toki Tori, their talent with creating tricky but doable puzzles is still readily apparent. I am not at all a fan of puzzle games as I get frustrated very quickly, so the fact I finished this one is probably everything a fan of the genre needs to know. Gameplay is deceptively simple- use redirectional tiles to guide a series of coloured blocks home. If you've seen the trailer, you already know everything you need to know in order to start playing. The layouts are fiendish though, and tease you with making it very clear what you HAVE to do, but keeping HOW to do it closely guarded. Many of the puzzles are forehead-slappingly clear once you figure it out, but until you get to that point you'll be dazed and confused trying to figure out how you're supposed to get THIS block over THERE with two Turn Left tiles and a Stop tile.Unfortunately the hardest levels tend to devolve into a confusing mess of tiles and blocks everywhere- while earlier levels it was clear where you were going wrong, later levels are so tightly packed it can be hard to figure out exactly what the problem with your solution is. However, the powerful in-built Hint system is tremendously helpful in untying these knots, and perhaps borders on being TOO helpful if you allow it to be- one button tells you if the tiles you have placed should be where they are or not, the other reveals the correct location of every tile you have (but not while tile to put in that place). With trial and error these hints can pretty much solve the puzzle for you, so stay strong-willed and only use it when you're completely against the wall!

TL;DRChallenging and engaging, RUSH is a puzzle game that keeps the player interested and involved the entire time.Square DancingYou don't need to break new ground to create a good game. RUSH is a puzzle game that's more of the same, but in a good way. The game itself isn't incredibly long (depending on how fast you solve the puzzles), but it feels rewarding. Each puzzle you struggle through feels like an accomplishment and each puzzle presents a whole new bag of tricks so that almost no two levels feel the same. RUSH is an excellent game, especially for the price.BreakdownPros Scaffolding: Even though RUSH does offer a few tutorial levels, the real learning happens as you're playing. The game's level design is well thought out as each level teaches you something you'll need in upcoming levels. Quality > Quantity: RUSH is a game that's as long as it needs to be. Many puzzlers attempt to pad playtime by having dozens of (what essentialy amounts to) the same level. Instead, RUSH doesn't overstay its welcome and gives the player the cream-of-the-crop. Secrets! Even for such a short game, RUSH contains a handful of secret levels and a bit of comedy (courtesy of GLaDOS).Cons Move B*tch, Get Out the Way: One thing this game does lack is a fast-forward button on the levels. Some long levels with slow-moving cubes will be the bane of your existance. Third-Eye Blind: The game does some wacky stuff and sometimes, it's a pain to try and position the camera juuuuusssst right to reach that one tile space. The ability to at least zoom in and out would've been great. Score: 9/10

												RUSH is a 3D indie puzzle game by Two Tribes[twotribes.com]. It's their second Windows release after the successful Toki Tori. In RUSH, the player needs to guide colored cubes to the appropriate exit points. This happens by using items that are unlocked through the progress of the game, such as Conveyor belts, Warps and more. The player places the items in advance and needs to imagine how they will affect the cubes' process through the level.I don't have much to say against this game, just one suggestion: a level editor would be great. After completing this game once, I have nothing more to do and there's no motivation for me to play it anymore. If there was an option to download community-created levels (for example through the Steam Workshop) and designing own levels, it would definitely raise the replay potential for me and probably many other players.Other than that, this game has great, tricky levels, for those who want a challenge, or if you want to set your mind at ease or are just stuck at one level for a while, there's a hint system that makes your life easier. The environment looks neat and clean, which contributes to the game's calming and relaxing feel along with a chill music and simple drag and drop controls. Everything about this game says "No rush." (such irony). On a gameplay level, I like the idea of the game, it's really simple but they did a good job implementing it, the levels have interesting and creative patterns, the items used to control the cubes are decent.Overall I'd recommend this game if you're a puzzle game fanatic or if you just want a calming game to free your mind. If you're none of these two, you might not have as much fun with the game as I did, but it's worth a try.

												A must have for any puzzler enthusiast's collection.RUSH is a 3d puzzle game involving simple logic skills. There's colored entrances and exits, and as soon as you believe you've finished the puzzle, blocks will teleport into existence and follow a straight line across the map, only turning right when they bump into walls.You, as the player, have to place special movement pads on the ground that influence the path these blocks take, allowing you to divert block traffic to help all of them reach the exit without colliding or falling off the map.While this premise sounds really simple, in practice it can get really complex because of this simplicity. There's 4 direction changing pads, a direction switcher that switches back and forth when blocks use it. A pause pad, as well as a conveyor belt pad. While their effects are simple, it's the entire contraption and combination of switching and redirecting traffic at the right place that turns out to be the big puzzling question in this game.The game divides the puzzles in a few difficulty settings, starting with tutorial/easy puzzles that only involve a few pads, up to hard and 'special' puzzles that require great insights and rational systematic analysis of the paths the cubes take to find out the solution. PresentationOriginally a WiiWare download title called Rubik's Puzzle Galaxy: Rush, the game has since lost its Rubik's licence, being released on Steam simply as Rush, with additional stages and content. Rush is a puzzle game, in which you are given a certain number of directional signs, stop signs or split signs which you can place on the map in order to guide each cube from point A to point B without them colliding or falling off the map. Those stages are grouped based on their difficulty starting with the easy ones, and moving on to the medium ones and the hard ones, allowing you to choose a challenge fit for your experience and get better with time, allowing you to learn from your mistakes, observe how the cubes move once you've hit the green button and rearrange the signs based on what you have seen. There is no sense of advancement since there is no leveling up system and you're not really unlocking anything besides the next levels, but playing Rush more will definitely make you better at it, as long as you keep replaying the same stage, since you're not exactly learning how to play the game better, but instead observing the problems in your sign arrangement; it's more like ruling out the bad solution and eventually getting to the right one, how long it takes to get there depends only on how well you understand the mechanics.Rating: 7GameplayThe gameplay is simplistic and intuitive, offering a challenge for everyone and satisfaction to those who dare to give the hardest levels a shot. Placing signs is easy and understanding how they work is the key to solving puzzles, while directional signs are the most encountered ones, using them efficiently is what will get you through as the natural direction of the cube plays an important role in many puzzles, and combining good use of direction movement with things such as speed which can be influenced using a stop sign or a directional sign, and the split sign which will allow you to group cubes based on their color in order to send them in the right direction, all matters in the end. There is also a hint system that will tell you where signs should be placed without giving the exact order, a tool that will come in handy for those who want to enjoy the game without wasting too much time on a single puzzle. There are levels grouped depending on the challenge level, but there's nothing stopping you from enjoying all of them, as the hard ones can be approached using the hint system and the easy ones can be fun even for the pros. Adding all that up, there are more than 80 different stages, with different levels of difficulty, so there's plenty of challenge for everyone.Rating: 7.5GraphicsRush is a colorful universe, using cubes and their respective colors to create beautiful backgrounds that will often captivate you more than the stage itself. Even though all the stages respect the same rules of color and formation, each one feels unique in its own way, and successfully solving a puzzle often rewards you with a beautiful parade of flawlessly moving blocks.Rating: 7AudioThe electronic soundtrack is in theme with the game, and even though the number of tracks is limited and will become repetitive eventually, you can always play Rush with your own music in the background since there is no dialogue or information given that you'll miss if you do that. The sound effects are okay, yet nothing spectacular to support the colorful movement of successfully guided blocks.Rating: 6.5ExtrasWith all its 80+ stages including the bonus stages and the special Portal Event stages, Rush can take anywhere from 3 hours to 10 hours to complete, depending how long it takes for you to give up and hit the hint button, but even so for a 5 bucks title, you get plenty of content to play around with.Rating: 7.5VerdictRush is a must play for puzzle fans who want a little challenge, but it still provides a few intriguing levels for the casual puzzle solvers too, so there are enough reasons for everyone to give it a shot and see how well they can guide the cubes.Rating Overall: 7.1Check out the full review and a lot more about RUSH at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=355

This game hits perfection almost everywhere, the pacing is fantastic, the controls are intuitive, and the art direction is very relevant to the game. However, the game completely lacks replayability and all the puzzles have very limited solutions. This is because each puzzles have a fixed amount of tiles and in almost every scenario in Rush, you will end up using them all. Regardless, the game is very high quality and for such a cheap price replayability is a non-issue.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												A perfect puzzle game. There are 4 simple rules: Get the blocks from where they appear to where they need to end up. If a block hits a wall, it turns 90 degrees. If a block rolls over an instruction tile you've placed down, it will follow that instruction. If a block is obstructed or falls off the map, then the game stops and you have to rethink what you're doing. Very simple mechanics mean the game is easily learned but by adding more layers, more blocks moving in parallel, and complex criss-crossing paths, the game gradually ramps up the difficulty until the hardest levels become a complex choreography of colours dancing all over the play area. The visual and audio design is crisp and clean: enough to get the core mechanics of the game across to the player, nothing to distract away from the gameplay, while looking and sounding great too.

												RUSH is a 3D puzzle game about "pathing":  blocks spawn and automatically move straight ahead, and directional floor tiles must be strategically placed to change the blocks' direction and guide them to the exit. There's plenty of levels at all difficulties and each one puts their own flavor on the same problem.
